question: Charge them...
answer: Good evening -- my key -- one sixty- eight.

question: Good evening, Mr. Pimenov.
answer: Oh -- good evening, Baron.

question: How's the beautiful lady?
answer: Grusinskaya -- well, to tell the truth, Baron -- tonight we are a little bit nervous. Were you at the theatre last night?

question: Certainly -- always when Grusinskaya dances.
answer: Well -- last night was not so good.

question: I thought she was splendid!
answer: Yes -- but the audience.

question: Ach! Here you are, Doctor Zinnowitz.
answer: Have I kept you waiting?

question: Waiting -- I'm waiting for news from Manchester.
answer: No news yet?

question: No. No word.
answer: Everything depends on the Manchester merger.

question: I know -- I know.
answer: I saw Gerstenkorn at lunch -- and as your lawyer I made it my business to broach the matter --- I'm expecting a young woman -- a stenographer -- she will ask for Mr. Preysing. Ask her to wait.

question: If a young woman, a stenographer, -- etc.
answer: Any letters?

question: No, Doctor.
answer: Telegrams?

question: No, Doctor.
answer: Anyone asked for me?

question: The war.
answer: That is Doctor Otternschlag -- You know him?

question: Yes -- He always seems to be waiting for something -- and nothing ever comes.
answer: The war dropped him here and forgot him.

question: If you will wait one moment, sir.
answer: I won't wait -- I can't wait -- I waited three days before I got a room at all and what a room that is.

question: It's a very nice room and inexpensive, sir.
answer: Did I say I wanted a cheap room to live in -- when I came here did I ask for a cheap room? Did I?

question: Just one moment, sir.
answer: No, I won't wait -- I can't -- Every day is precious -- every hour -- Every minute. I came here because I wanted to live here, two weeks, maybe three -- God only knows -- I've told you I'll pay -- I'll pay anything you ask. I'm tired -- I'm ill -- I can't wait.

question: The gentleman is dissatisfied with room number five fifty-nine.
answer: I certainly have a complaint -- and a fair one. I came here from a long distance to stay at the Grand Hotel. I want a room -- a big room -- like you would give General Director Preysing -- I'm as good as Mr. Preysing -- I can pay like Mr. Preysing -- would you give him a little room, way up in the corner with the hot water pipes going -- bang -- bang -- bang...

question: I certainly have a complaint -- and a fair one. I came here from a long distance to stay at the Grand Hotel. I want a room -- a big room -- like you would give General Director Preysing -- I'm as good as Mr. Preysing -- I can pay like Mr. Preysing -- would you give him a little room, way up in the corner with the hot water pipes going -- bang -- bang -- bang...
answer: This gentleman can have my room.

question: Oh!
answer: Send his bags up to my room.

question: Oh -- but -- I --
answer: You're tired. I can see that.

question: Yes -- yes -- I am tired. I have been ill...
answer: You are ill.

question: Does that mean that the bath is my own? --- Private? Well, now, that's very kind -- thanks. That's what I want -- a large room on the front with a private bath -- Yes, that's what I want. I can pay now if you like.
answer: That will not be necessary.

question: Thank you, sir.
answer: Not at all, sir.

question: Permit me -- my name is Kringelein -- from Fredersdorf.
answer: I'm Baron von Gaigern.

question: Oh, a Baron!
answer: And this is Doctor Otternschlag.

question: Yes -- Oh -- oh -- yes, --
answer: Well, Baron -- I must go and dress.

question: Is this gentleman a Baron, too?
answer: Unfortunately no.

question: Have you a minute now?
answer: No -- I told you not to come in this lobby.

question: Time's getting short.
answer: I've told you a hundred times not to speak to me with a cigarette in your mouth.

question: I want to speak --
answer: Not now.

question: Don't hurry -- take your time.
answer: Like dancing?

question: Not with strangers.
answer: Never?

question: You're a fool!
answer: Yes, I am rather. He must be very nice.

question: Who?
answer: Whoever is keeping you waiting.

question: Have you seen it?
answer: Oh, my large and noisy neighbor -- really? That?

question: That.
answer: You?

question: Oh -- work!!
answer: Oh!

question: Dictation. You know...
answer: Oh... poor child. If you were free, I'd ask you to come and have some tea -- but --

question: Tea would spoil my dinner. One meal a day, I'd hate to spoil it.
answer: Reducing?

question: No -- why? -- should I?
answer: Lord no -- charming -- but why one meal a day?

question: Money -- Ever heard of it?
answer: Yes -- yes indeed -- but you are a... ...a stenographer. Don't little stenographers earn little pennies?

question: Very little.
answer: Too bad.

question: Did you ever see a stenographer with a decent frock on? -- One that she'd bought herself?
answer: Poor child -- I wish I were free tonight -- we could --

question: Aren't you?
answer: What?

question: Free --
answer: Unfortunately no -- to bad -- tomorrow though.

question: Tomorrow? What time tomorrow?
answer: Shall we say five o'clock -- downstairs?

question: Where downstairs?
answer: Yellow Room where they dance --

question: You're very funny --
answer: Yes? -- Tomorrow?

question: Of course.
answer: Really? We'll dance.

question: Shot from her angle. She is sleeping beneath a Chinese robe, on the chaise-lounge. No, I have been awake -- thinking -- thinking. The performance?
answer: It is time.

question: Always the performance -- every day the performance -- time for the performance. I think, Suzette, I have never been so tired in my life. Veronal didn't even help me to sleep.
answer: Madam Grusinskaya's car is to be brought.

question: I can't dance tonight --
answer: It will pass -- it will pass -- come.

question: Let us cancel the engagement.
answer: But, Madam. cannot do that.

question: Now is the time to cancel to stop entirely. I feel it -- everything tells me -- enough -- enough. The peals are cold -- everything is cold -- finished -- it seems so far away -- so threadbare -- the Russians -- St. Petersburg -- the Imperial Court -- the Grand Duke Sergei -- -- Sergei -- dead -- Grusinskaya -- it's all gone.
answer: Mon Dieu -- the pearls -- if they were to break --

question: The pearls won't break -- they hold together and bring me bad luck ---- I hate them!
answer: Orchids come again, Madam -- no card -- I think perhaps they are from the same young man -- he is at the end of the corridor -- tall -- he walks like a soldier -- Madam must have noticed how often he is in the elevator with us. Last night for instance --

question: Oh, Suzette -- Suzette -- Sshh -- quiet.
answer: Ah, oui -- the car is here for Madam.

question: Send it away -- I shan't need it. Come in. Madam Grusinskaya will not require her car -- no -- she will not be going to the theatre.
answer: It is time for the performance.

question: The performance -- the performance -- the performance.
answer: Poor little Lisevata -- she still has her stage frights -- it will pass.

question: It is not stage fright -- it's something more --
answer: What -- what is it? Last night...

question: Last night?... There was no applause.
answer: There was -- there was.

question: That theatre -- half empty -- dancing for those few -- I was frantic -- I finished -- the last beat and... ...I waited -- I listened -- but the applause didn't come -- nothing. A man in the box -- and just the claques behind -- it is passed, Pimenov. We are dead -- it's finished.
answer: Meierheim --

question: What is this that you have cancelled your car? Who am I that I should wait like a fool at the door? And here on a whim, you cancel your car. Have you forgotten there is a performance? Do you know the time? Or, are we all mad? Am I your manager?... Have we a contract? Have we obligations? Am I blind? ...Or is that the time?
answer: I'm cancelling the engagement.

question: Oh! Oh! Madam is cancelling the engagement. Madam has chosen a funny time for such a funny joke. Ha, ha, ha -- hurry, come on. Tonight -- there's a line in front of the theatre since six o'clock. The house is jammed to the roof.
answer: The house is not full -- Is it really full?

question: Packed to the ceiling. Hurry -- get dressed. And what an audience -- the French Ambassador -- American Millionaires -- Princess Ratzville -- er -- er --
answer: Oh -- but it can't be.

question: We will wait.
answer: You are late. Hurry. Tell Madam Grusinskaya's chauffeur to bring the car.

question: How is the house?
answer: Terrible. After this, no more ballets for me. Jazz -- Just jazz.

question: If the house is empty again, I don't know --
answer: When she gets her paint on and hears the music -- she'll be all right. I know these people.

question: You may laugh. Caviar and champagne may mean nothing to you, but to me -- they mean a great deal. You see, I'm ill and all of a sudden I got a fear of missing life. I don't want to miss life -- do you understand?
answer: You are funny. You speak of life as if it were a train you wanted to catch.

question: Yes -- and for me, it's going to leave at any minute. Let's drink. I'm sure this beautiful room must appeal to your taste -- distinctive, don't you think? Velvet upholstery -- 'A-number one'. I'm in the textile trade and I know. And these are real silk drapes.
answer: Silk -- think of that -- silk -- they are, too.

question: Her master's voice! I must go now -- goodbye -- thanks.
answer: Oh, don't go.

question: I'm engaged for the evening.
answer: Oh, can anyone engage you for the evening?

question: What's the matter, Mr. Kringelein?
answer: General Director Preysing! Baron, when I was sixteen years old, I started as an office boy in that man's factory --

question: Then you know him?
answer: Do I know him -- I know him through and through.

question: I must -- I hope to see you again, Mr. Kringelein.
answer: You will stay, Doctor -- if you have nothing better to do?

question: My coat. Suzette -- I told you not to bring the pearls. I will not wear them tonight.
answer: Why not?

question: Take them back, Suzette.
answer: You haven't time.

question: Hurry, Suzette.
answer: Such nonsense. The car for Madam Grusinskaya.

question: No news from Manchester yet -- Do you think we ought to postpone the conference?
answer: Good heavens no. That'd create the very worst impression. You must be optimistic. You must convince them. You know as well as I do that the merger must go through.

question: Yes -- the merger must go through -- But I am used to making my deals on a solid basis. I am not a liar. I am an honest business man -- a good husband and father -- I have a sense of honor -- I have nothing to conceal. I couldn't live happily otherwise.
answer: Well, don't get excited about it. We agreed that the merger with the Saxonia people must go through.

question: I want to dictate my statement for tomorrow. I can't speak without notes. I like to have things down before me in black and white.
answer: I'll see you in the morning then, at the conference. Everything'll be all right, Preysing... Don't worry. Goodnight.

question: Good night. Moreover --
answer: Moreover --

question: Moreover -- Is there a telegram for me yet?... Oh -- when it does, send it up. Now, where was I? Oh -- sorry. Where was I?
answer: Moreover...

question: Moreover... Do you work in Justice Zinnowitz' office?
answer: No -- only occasional jobs.

question: Tired?
answer: You pay me.

question: You're a very unusual stenographer --
answer: Moreover...

question: Moreover...
answer: I don't see why it's unusual for a stenographer to be pretty -- if she does her work well, -- seems so silly. I don't know why they don't like girls like me in offices. Personally, I hate offices -- I'd much rather be in the movies.

question: Movies?
answer: Yes, I photograph very well. Look --

question: What is this?
answer: I got ten marks for that.

question: You...
answer: Me.

question: You...
answer: Moreover...

question: What?
answer: Only in mutual advantages -- moreover.

question: What brown hands you have.
answer: That's from skiing.

question: Skiing?
answer: Yes... A man I know took me to Switzerland last month...

question: A man? -- To Switzerland? -- That must have been nice -- for him.
answer: Only in mutual advantages -- moreover...

question: Moreover... He was a lucky man -- that man.
answer: Perhaps.

question: Don't misunderstand me. I'm a married man -- with grownup daughters. Uh --
answer: Moreover -- Do you mind if I smoke? I went to Florence once, too.

question: With the same friend?
answer: No.

question: Moreover, the possibility of the successful termination of negotiations now pending with the Manchester Cotton Company...
answer: Not too quickly.

question: What?
answer: You're a little too fast.

question: Can't you understand me?
answer: I understand you perfectly.

question: Have you got it now?
answer: Cotton Company --

question: Should throw a great weight into the balance...
answer: ...weight into the balance...

question: Come in. Oh -- oh.
answer: Deal with Manchester Cotton Company definitely off. Sorry. How nice -- your daughters?

question: My daughters -- yes, my daughters.
answer: Is that Mrs. Preysing.

question: Definitely off.
answer: Oh -- too bad. Did you quarrel?

question: You are late -- the dancer's gone to the theatre.
answer: Well?

question: She's gone to the theatre -- don't you know?
answer: Yes.

question: And what are you going to do?
answer: The pearls are in her room.

question: Now listen to me. The others are getting suspicious of you. I was on the telephone to Amsterdam today, they think you're scared.
answer: I've been careful, I've been waiting my chance.

question: You've been waiting your chance. You're too much of a gentleman -- that's the trouble with you.
answer: I told you I'll get the pearls tonight.

question: Need any help?
answer: No.

question: Have you got that skeleton key?
answer: No --

question: Why?
answer: The floor clerk is out there in the corridor -- she sees everything ---

question: I could take care of her.
answer: How?

question: Chloroform on a handkerchief from behind -- while you...
answer: No -- no -- no -- no...

question: Why?
answer: Poor girl -- chloroform would give her a rotten headache... I know -- I had it in the war. Besides, she's very pretty -- not young but --

question: You're no good for this business. It's just a joke to you...
answer: I don't like your tone.

question: No --
answer: Get out and leave it to me... be ready to leave on the night train for Amsterdam...

question: With the pearls?
answer: With the pearls --

question: Hello, hello, Mr. Pimenov? Yes... Mr. Pimenov, have they found her?... No, she is not here... Yes, I'm at the hotel.
answer: Pimenov?... What's happening?... No, I haven't found her. Is Desprez dancing?... How is it?... Oh, all right. Keep the show going. Wait till I see her, she'll pay for this -- this little trick is going to cost Grusinskaya a suit for breach of contract.

question: Madame is ill -- her nerves...
answer: Her nerves... What about my nerves?... Who is she anyway? Where does she think she is -- Russia? Those days have passed.

question: Madame --
answer: Well?

question: Suzette, please go, I want to be alone.
answer: I suppose I can cancel the Vienna engagement.

question: I wish to be alone.
answer: You'll be very much alone, my dear madame. This is the end.

question: Quite suddenly -- as if with resolution she begins to undress. Then she becomes weary again.
answer: We see him tense himself.

question: She drops the garment listlessly to the floor -- moves out of scene. She is in a thin robe. She sits before mirror -- looks steadily at her face. Her head goes down suddenly in her hands and we hear her say: The end -- over -- finished -- The Western Theatre -- Western Theatre? The stage -- Mr. Pimonov -- the ballet master... Grusinskaya -- hurry -- hurry. Yes -- yes, I'm waiting. Hello, Pimenov? -- I'm at the hotel. I couldn't go on -- I couldn't... No, no don't -- ...Just alone... Good night, good night, my dear -- goodbye... Pimenov, how is it going, badly?... Uh?... Who's dancing?... Desprez?... Oh -- and how is it?... Oh, -- oh, I see -- they didn't miss me?... They didn't miss me. They didn't miss me -- good night, Pimenov... Oh -- I'm sorry, yes... I have finished.
answer: Please, do not be alarmed, Madam. Careful -- there's broken glass on the floor. There. Please do not be frightened, Madam.

question: What do you want here?
answer: Nothing -- only to be here.

question: Why do you hide in my room?
answer: But surely you must know -- because I love you.

question: Because you love me -- you love me?
answer: Poor little Grusinskaya! Does it do you good to cry? Are you afraid? Shall I go?

question: I was so alone -- always alone -- and suddenly you were there and said that. No. I am not afraid. It is strange.
answer: Don't cry -- it tears my heart to see you sob like that.

question: Nerves -- just nerves. You must forgive me. I have had a bad evening. I am very tired. Do you know what it is to be tired -- tired of a routine existence?
answer: I'm afraid not -- I usually do just what I feel like doing at the moment.

question: So you feel like coming into a lady's room -- and you come... What now?
answer: I'd like to smoke a cigarette.

question: Certainly. Why do you look at me like that?
answer: I did not know you were so beautiful... and --

question: And then --?
answer: No irony. You're so appealing -- so soft -- so tired. I feel like taking you in my arms and not letting anything more happen to you -- ever.

question: And -- and --
answer: How tired you are!

question: Yes -- tired...
answer: So alone.

question: Alone. All alone. Oh, you strange -- strange creature.
answer: You mustn't talk Russian to me.

question: Strange man...
answer: Am I quite strange to you?

question: Not quite strange now. It is as if I had been expecting you. You know, once when the Grand Duke was alive, I found a man hiding in my room -- a young officer --
answer: And...?

question: He disappeared. Later he was found dead.
answer: I never knew it was so dangerous to hide in a woman's room when she's alone.

question: Go away. Who are you --?
answer: A man who could love -- that is all, who has forgotten everything else for you.

question: You could love me. It is so long since I have heard that word. Nobody has loved me for a long time. It is so icy-cold to be famous. One is so cruelly alone. How is it that you -- Let me look at you. Your hands. Your eyes. Why could you love me?
answer: I saw you just now -- then I saw you cry -- and now I see you in the mirror -- Grusinskaya...

question: Grusinskaya... Oh -- oh if you knew how I slaved and slaved for Grusinskaya -- for the success of Grusinskaya -- for the triumph of Grusinskaya... and what is she now? Just someone who has found that on the day success ceases life ceases -- Are you listening to me -- Do you understand? -- I want you to understand.
answer: Yes -- I do understand.

question: I think you must go now -- the key is on the floor.
answer: I'm not going -- You know I'm not going -- Let me stay here?

question: I want to be alone.
answer: That is not so -- you don't want to be alone.

question: I want to be alone --
answer: No -- You don't want to be alone at all -- You were in despair before -- If I left you, you'd feel worse than you did before, You must not be alone -- You mustn't cry -- you must forget... Tell me that I can stay with you -- tell me.

question: Just for a minute then.
answer: What? Say it again -- I didn't hear.

question: You -- man... Thank you -- you are gallant. What a sentimental scene. Grusinskaya weeping is a sight worth seeing. It is many years since she did such a thing... You frightened me -- badly. You're responsible for this -- painful scene. The stage frays one's nerves... the discipline -- it's so exacting. Discipline means doing what you don't want to do and take no pleasure in doing. Do you know what I mean? Have you ever experienced the weariness that comes from discipline?
answer: I? -- Oh, no. I do only what I take pleasure in doing.

question: I see -- you do only what you take pleasure in doing. You take pleasure in coming into a woman's bedroom and you come. You take pleasure in a dangerous climb onto a balcony, so you do it... And what is your pleasure now?
answer: I should like to smoke.

question: Why do you smile?
answer: Because I can see something in the mirror that you cannot. My dear --

question: What can you see?
answer: You are beautiful!

question: No.
answer: Beautiful but so sad. I did not know it was so dangerous to look into a woman's bedroom.

question: I think you had better go now. The key is on the floor.
answer: I'm not going... You know that I'm not going... Do you think I could leave you alone here? After that --?

question: What?
answer: The veronal -- you. I'm going to stay here with you.

question: I want to be alone.
answer: That is not the truth. You do not want to be alone -- you're afraid of being alone -- I know you're afraid. I know you. You were desperate, just now, if I go away you'll be more desperate than ever. Say I am to stay with you... say it.

question: For just a minute then. No -- oh, no!
answer: Just for a minute, Grusinskaya --

question: Oh, but Doctor. Isn't this wonderful. To live -- to live -- in the Grand Hotel.
answer: The Grand Hotel.

question: Oh, but Doctor. The music -- the champagne -- girls when they dance -- all the shining ice in those big silver things -- That's life --
answer: Life! -- Mr. Kringelein, you are drunk -- good night.

question: Manchester -- yes -- yes. A man in the textile industry naturally has to know Manchester.
answer: There's a lot of business to be done with the Manchester Cotton Company. They've the whole English market right in their hands. Have you any connections with -- Manchester?

question: We have a good many connections in England, naturally.
answer: I mean with the Manchester people?

question: We are here to discuss our merger. Naturally I can make no statement at this time. We must begin at the beginning.
answer: All right.

question: Since, on the eleventh of June, this year -- when the first negotiations for a merger between our respective firms was entered into -- both parties have fully agreed that this merger can result only in mutual advantages.
answer: Oh -- yes -- I beg your pardon!

question: I'm laying before you the last general statement of our concern. Active capital, plant and machinery, raw material and finished product -- for instance -- mop rags --
answer: Mop rags --! What we want to know about is Manchester.

question: Oh -- I was ambitious then -- ambition was in my blood -- no rest, no stopping. We were drilled like little soldiers -- We danced in the school of the Imperial Ballet, in St. Petersburg. I was little and slim but hard as diamond -- a duty machine -- No rest, no stopping. And then -- I became famous and whoever is famous is alone... But why should I be telling you this? Last night I did not know you at all -- who are you, really? -- I do not even know your name.
answer: I am Felix Benvenuto von Gaigern. My mother called me Flix.

question: Flix. -- And how do you live? What kind of a person are you?
answer: I'm a prodigal son, the black sheep of a white flock -- I shall die on the gallows.

question: Really?
answer: Really, I haven't a bit of character. None at all.

question: No?
answer: When I was a little boy I was taught to ride and be a gentleman -- at school, it was a monastery, I learned to pray and lie -- and ---

question: And?
answer: And then, in the war, to kill and hide. That's all.

question: And what do you do -- now?
answer: I'm a gambler -- I'm running at large like a happy pig, devouring anything of life that pleases me, I really belong in jail

question: Oh! What a picture -- and what else?
answer: I'm also a criminal and a hotel thief.

question: That's a silly joke.
answer: Please look at me. You must believe me -- you must believe that I love you -- that I have never known what love is -- until last night.

question: What is the matter? Flix!
answer: There.

question: Oh -- Did you come here just -- just for that? Oh -- it's horrible. You may keep the pearls -- I don't want them any more -- I'll make you a present of them.
answer: I don't want them now.

question: I'll not denounce you.
answer: I know.

question: So --
answer: Yesterday I was a thief -- but now, --

question: But now, you must go... I give you the pearls. But now you must go ---
answer: I wanted money desperately -- Can you understand? -- That's why I wanted the pearls. I was threatened -- I was desperately in need of a certain big sum of money. I've been following you -- I've admired you. But I have forced myself not to think about you -- Last night, at last, I managed to came into your room and -- and now.

question: And now?
answer: I couldn't go through with it. Remarkable. Do you understand?

question: Yes -- yes -- yes. Quickly -- here. Good morning, Suzette.
answer: Good morning, Madam. Madam has slept well?

question: Oh, yes, Suzette.
answer: Madam will dress now, it is late.

question: Five minutes, Suzette, come back in five minutes. I'll ring.
answer: Yes, madam Suzette knows all about it. Madam is beautiful this morning.

question: Yes, Suzette. You must go now. There -- it begins. Hello -- hello -- Meierheim? Yes... No -- What?... Cancel Vienna?... Are you mad? We always have great success in Vienna... Certainly not. Come here and see me... yes... good-bye. There -- the day begins... I must go to rehearsal.
answer: Grusinskaya --

question: Yes.
answer: You do believe that I really love you?

question: Yes -- If I didn't believe that, I'd die after last night.
answer: I want to be good to you -- madly good.

question: Suzette will be back here in a minute.
answer: I'll go -- good-bye.

question: Shall I see you again? Suzette will be back here any minute.
answer: When are you leaving Berlin?

question: Very early in the morning.
answer: For Vienna?

question: Can't -- can't you -- Couldn't you come too -- I think it would be better -- for us -- for us both.
answer: Oh -- yes but -- later.

question: Why later?
answer: I have no money now -- I must get some first -- I must get some.

question: I'll give you what you need -- I have money.
answer: Oh no -- that would spoil everything. I'll -- I will manage somehow -- I'll manage myself. I will go with you. When does the train leave?

question: Six twenty-seven in the morning... But the money?
answer: Never mind -- I'll get it. I have a whole day. I'll be on that train.

question: I shall dance and you'll be with me and then -- listen -- After that you will come with me to Lake Como, I have a villa there. The sun will be shining. I will take a vacation -- six weeks -- eight weeks. We'll be happy and lazy. And then you will go with me to South America -- oh! You must go now. Be careful on your way to your room.
answer: I'll go. -- I love you. I'll be on that train. I'll get the money.

question: Don't do anything foolish -- I'm alarmed about you.
answer: Don't worry. I'll be on the train. He leaves.

question: Yes, Pimenov... Yes... where are you, in your room? Come, I will see you now... hurry. Not that dark dress -- something light -- bright -- it's a sunny morning, Suzette. Come in. Good morning, Pimenov.
answer: Good morning, Gru -- your --

question: Pimenov, I have an idea -- a new ballet -- it must have mad music -- I'll explain it to you later. But now, hurry to the theatre -- I want full rehearsal -- properties -- full ballet and some musicians. Hurry -- Quickly. I will be there --
answer: Gru -- you are positively radiant.

question: You've talked enough today, you're hoarse now. Sorry, Preysing.
answer: You've decided against the merger?

question: Yes --
answer: Then, it's all over?

question: Goodbye, Preysing, I hope you pull through. This is a very bad time to be in such a crisis. We've...
answer: Why talk -- it's over -- it's over -- it's finished. You've broken off negotiations. You did it. You're calling them off. You had nothing on your mind all day, but Manchester, -- Manchester -- Manchester. You don't suppose for one moment that I'm such a fool as not to have something that I could say definitely about Manchester.

question: What?
answer: Oh no -- no -- the session is over. Let's go, it's off. Thank you, gentlemen.

question: If you actually have news from Manchester then...
answer: Gentlemen, I am now free to announce... ...that the deal between my firm and the Manchester Cotton Company has been successfully negotiated.

question: In that case give us the articles. We'll sign at once. We know all the details...
answer: I thought we'd suspended negotiations, gentlemen.

question: Under these circumstances it's quite a different matter.
answer: Under these circumstances we might refuse to sign.

question: Next week. Next week.
answer: You let me talk till I'm hoarse and you had Manchester sewed-up all the time. Why? Well -- the deal has been put through.

question: Yes, it has been put through -- it has been put through.
answer: What's the matter with you?

question: Bluff -- Bluff -- all bluff.
answer: What's bluff?

question: That.
answer: 'Deal with Manchester definitely off! "Preysing, oh -- I'd never have thought it of you.

question: No one would have thought it of me. I've been getting rusty in Fredersdorf. Well, if bluff is what the world wants I guess I can put up as big a bluff as anyone. From now on...
answer: You must go to Manchester at once yourself and really see it through.

question: Yes -- I must go to England -- I was desperate -- Now I don't care -- This sort of thing goes to a man's head.
answer: What you need is some relaxation.

question: Yes -- that's what I want -- I'd like to tear loose -- I'd like a drink. I'd like to go down to that dancing place. I'd like to start something.
answer: I can understand that -- after your -- uh --

question: Say it -- say it -- my lie -- it's the first time in thirty years that I've ever... Where's that stenographer? Miss Flaemm...
answer: What do you want with her?

question: I want to see her, I want to do some dictating -- report of the conference for my father-in-law.
answer: She had an engagement in the Yellow Room at five o'clock -- she was in a hurry.

question: Zinnowitz, would you say she was pretty?
answer: Pretty as a picture.

question: Let's go down and find her -- I need a drink -- Come along Zinnowitz. I don't know anything about women -- been married for twenty-six years.
answer: Bluff does it, Preysing, bluff does it. Goodnight.

question: Good evening, Mr. Kringelein -- Where's the Baron?
answer: I'm waiting for him here. The Baron and I have been together all day. A hundred miles an hour -- in a motor car -- and in an aeroplane -- It was marvelous --

question: Mr. Kringelein -- How you have changed, you look so nice.
answer: Oh, thank you, Miss Flaemm. Oh, please, Miss Flaemm -- Permit me, Miss Flaemm, won't you have something sweet -- a Louisiana flip. A Louisiana flip.

question: No - absinthe.
answer: Yes -- that --

question: You like music?
answer: Yes -- it's stimulating -- a man might --

question: A man might what?
answer: I don't know -- I'd like to do anything --

question: What have you been doing all day?
answer: Chasing around.

question: Chasing what?
answer: Money.

question: You were very different yesterday.
answer: Yesterday -- yes -- that was yesterday.

question: Well, Mr. Kringelein, are you getting what you're looking for?
answer: What, Doctor?

question: A masculine paradise -- drink, the ladies, dancing...
answer: I had a very good opportunity, a young lady asked me to dance -- I ought to be able to dance, it seems to be very important.

question: You must learn as quickly as your time allows -- Believe me Mr. Kringelein, a man who isn't with a woman is a dead man.
answer: Haven't you anyone -- Haven't you anybody -- you -- I mean -- Are you all alone in the world.

question: I'm always alone -- I have been everything.
answer: Everything?

question: That was lovely.
answer: Will you do me a big favor?

question: I'll do anything for you.
answer: Would you like to make a man happy?

question: Yes -- I'd love to.
answer: Then dance the next number with Kringelein.

question: Why?
answer: I feel sorry for him.

question: You're not a bit like you were yesterday.
answer: I fell in love last night -- the real thing.

question: Oh -- there's no real thing -- it doesn't exist.
answer: I thought that, too -- but I found that it does. Come along, dance with Kringelein.

question: Anything for you.
answer: Miss Flaemm.

question: Hello!
answer: I must speak with you, Miss Flaemm.

question: Presently, Mr. Preysing.
answer: It's urgent.

question: Come and dance with me, Mr. Kringelein.
answer: I must speak to you, Miss Flaemm -- business.

question: Tomorrow morning.
answer: No -- now.

question: Do you gentlemen know each other, Mr. Kringelein -- Mr. Preysing -- Baron von Gaigern.
answer: Mr. Kringelein will be a good friend and not accept your invitation to dance.

question: I'll remember you, Mr. Kringelein.
answer: Oh, let the poor devil alone.

question: I did not ask your advice.
answer: I think it would be much better if you went away.

question: We shall see who remains here the longer.
answer: As you will.

question: You must look at my face and not at the floor.
answer: Yes.

question: You're trembling.
answer: I never danced before -- in public.

question: You dance splendidly.
answer: I'm happy, Miss Flaemm.

question: Really?
answer: For the first time in my life, I'm happy.

question: Let's stop -- I'm tired.
answer: Thank you, Miss Flaemm.

question: Thank you, Miss Flaemm.
answer: Well now, Miss Flaemm, we can talk.

question: Some champagne, Miss Flaemm?
answer: You may go, Mr. Kringelein.

question: Does the world belong to you, Mr. Preysing?
answer: What is this insolence?

question: Do you think you have free license to be insulting? Believe me you have not. You think you're superior, but you're quite an ordinary man.
answer: Go away -- go away.

question: You don't like to see me enjoying myself.
answer: Who are you? -- An embezzler most likely.

question: An embezzler -- you're going to take that back, right here in the presence of this young lady -- who do you think you're talking to? You think I'm dirt, if I'm dirt, you're a lot dirtier, Mr. Industrial Magnate Preysing.
answer: You're discharged.

question: Me?
answer: Yes you -- shut your mouth -- get out -- you're discharged.

question: Oh, yes, Mr. Preysing?
answer: Sit here. Cognac -- for you?

question: Nothing.
answer: I'm going to keep an eye on that Kringelein fellow. I'll find out where he gets the money to hang around the Grand Hotel.

question: Well -- you want me?
answer: Yes.

question: Well?
answer: I must go to England -- at once.

question: Well?
answer: You see, I'd like to take a secretary with me for my correspondence and -- humm -- humm -- for company on the trip -- I'm nervous -- I need somebody -- I don't know if you quite understand me. You said you have travelled with gentlemen -- and I mean --

question: I understand perfectly.
answer: What do you think your salary would be -- for such a trip?

question: Wait -- I must figure it up. First, I'll need -- clothes -- shoes -- it's cold in England in March, I'll need a suit... You'd want me to look nice?
answer: Of course -- of course.

question: A thousand marks --
answer: It's agreed -- I will get a room here for you. I can get a room here in the Grand Hotel for you. Can you pay some attention to me?

question: Oh, yes.
answer: Insolent young cub!

question: You mean Baron von Gaigern?
answer: Baron!

question: The Baron is tired?
answer: No, Kringelein, not tired, -- just -- Well -- well --

question: Perhaps this evening, Baron, we could go to the Casino -- the place we passed with the marvelous bright lights?
answer: I'd like to Kringelein, but I can't -- I am broke!

question: Broke -- A Baron? But, Baron --
answer: Excuse me, Mr. Kringelein. I've quit.

question: Excuse me, Mr. Kringelein. I've quit.
answer: You can't.

question: I'm not going to get those pearls and neither are you.
answer: What about the money?

question: I'll pay you back.
answer: How?

question: I have an idea working in my head...
answer: You might find a bullet through that head...

question: Later.
answer: Go on please -- go on, Suzette.

question: Bless you...
answer: Are you coming to the theatre? Oh -- I shall dance tonight -- How I shall dance -- I want to feel that you are in the theatre.

question: I can't.
answer: No?

question: No! I can't explain now. Oh, look -- the pearls. You wear them now...
answer: Why do you think --

question: Why?
answer: They've brought me such good luck -- you -- I'm worried about you.

question: Don't.
answer: On the train?

question: Yes -- I will be on the train.
answer: Till then.

question: Bless you --
answer: Was the Baron joking, or is it really true that the Baron is -- in financial straits.

question: Absolutely true, Kringelein and I have to raise some money immediately.
answer: If the Baron -- if you would permit me --

question: What?
answer: I would be awfully glad to oblige, you've been so decent to me. Three hundred?

question: If I could get into a game I might win some.
answer: Gambling! I'd like that. I have over six thousand eight hundred marks with me.

question: If we could scare up some men to play.
answer: We could come to my room.

question: That was my last.
answer: You've lost everything?

question: I've no luck.
answer: Pardon me, Baron. Permit me again...

question: Drink to me, Kringelein -- it's my last chance.
answer: I do drink, Baron -- I drink to you, Baron and to win. It's good, -- come along, Baron.

question: I take five hundred.
answer: All of that at once, Baron?

question: Oh, don't go, gentlemen! -- Stay a while. Be my guests! I oughtn't to presume, but I -- I'm so grateful to you -- it's been so marvelous. The first time in my life I have gambled -- I've danced! Oh, you can laugh, gentlemen, but it's the first time in my life I've ever tasted life!
answer: Splendid!

question: Life, gentlemen, is wonderful, but very dangerous. You must have courage for it, then it's wonderful. You gentlemen don't know that because you are all healthy and happy, but I -- believe me -- a man must know death and not until then does a man know anything about life.
answer: Rejoice in life while yet the small lamp burns. It's a short life and a gay one...

question: Goodnight. Flaemmchen, what are you doing here in the middle of the night.
answer: Looking for my room -- one sixty- six.

question: You live here?
answer: For tonight.

question: Oh!
answer: Yes -- oh!

question: Well -- such is life, Flaemmchen.
answer: And Baron, thanks so much for everything.

question: And Baron, thanks so much for everything.
answer: Flaemmchen! You are late. I've been waiting for you -- waiting.

question: I had to arrange about the trip.
answer: You're sweet.

question: You think so?
answer: Come here.

question: Here, hold up! Oh -- careful, Mr. Preysing.
answer: Call me -- do you know -- would you -- would you like to call me by my first name?

question: Oh, no.
answer: Why not?

question: I couldn't do that, you're a stranger to me.
answer: You're a funny little creature, Flaemmchen. I can't make you out.

question: It's not funny at all. One can't get intimate just off hand. I could go to England with you and everything like that -- supposing I met you next year and I said That's all quite proper. But supposing I met you when you were with your wife and I called out
answer: Please, Flaemmchen -- we'll leave my wife out of this.

question: All right. I'll get undressed -- get out.
answer: Aha! -- The Baron. What do you want here?

question: Aha! -- The Baron. What do you want here?
answer: I must have made a mistake.

question: Made a mistake -- remarkable. We shall soon see if you made a mistake. Stay here... Give me that money. So that's how we stand, Baron.
answer: Look here, sir -- I'm completely at your mercy -- I'm desperate -- it's a matter of life or death -- I had to get some money -- tonight.

question: Indeed you must, Baron -- you must. Humm -- humm, but you must go to jail, Baron, you're a thief.
answer: Be quiet.

question: I'm going to call the police. I'm going to watch you play the great Baron with the police. Aristocrat! Aristocrat! The door is locked, Baron. Hello! Hello! --
answer: Don't do that.

question: Mr. Kringelein -- Mr. Kringelein -- where are you? Quick -- Mr. Kringelein.
answer: Oh -- what -- what -- Oh -- oh, Miss Flaemmchen. It's you --

question: Quick -- something awful -- awful has happened. Go -- go at once, -- Mr. Preysing --
answer: Preysing?

question: Oh, don't wait -- go -- it's awful -- it's awful.
answer: Stay here.

question: Don't wait now -- go -- Preysing.
answer: Mr. Preysing -- Oh, Mr. Preysing -- Oh -- the Baron -- the Baron.

question: Mr. Preysing -- Oh, Mr. Preysing -- Oh -- the Baron -- the Baron.
answer: He tried to rob me -- he is dead --

question: My best friend -- poor, Baron -- dead -- just like that.
answer: -- We must do something...

question: Yes, the police must be called.
answer: No -- no -- wait -- the man was a burglar -- he was going to steal my money.

question: Oh, no -- no -- not the Baron.
answer: Where is that girl -- she was working with him -- she enticed me into her room.

question: Her room -- oh -- I see, Mr. Preysing -- I understand, Mr. General Director Preysing.
answer: I can answer for this, it was self- defense -- I can answer for this -- but that girl -- the scandal -- my wife -- my daughters, you know them?

question: Yes, I know them --
answer: The scandal -- we are men -- you -- you could take that affair of the young lady upon yourself -- take her and hold your tongue. Then you can travel -- I'll give you anything -- anything -- she was with you.

question: We must call the police, your excellency.
answer: How much -- how much do you want -- you need money -- you have nothing.

question: Madam should sleep.
answer: I've done my hair differently -- do you like that?

question: When a lady falls in love she does her hair differently.
answer: In the middle of the night -- those flowers make me think of a funeral. Laurels and tube-roses. Oh, think, Suzette -- the Villa and the sun at Tremezzo -- quiet -- simple -- happy -- we'll have a guest, Suzette.

question: Yes, Madam. And now Madam will sleep. It is not long 'till the train.
answer: Goodnight, Suzette. Hello -- can you tell me if Baron von Gaigern is in his room -- ring him. Cherie, I must wake you or you'll miss the train. ...yes... are you ringing, he may be asleep. Cherie, you must get up and fetch me from my room -- I'm longing for you, Cherie -- I have not been to sleep -- I kept thinking you would come to me. ...Oh, but he must answer. Ring -- ring -- ring. Cherie, hurry -- hurry -- hurry. Answer the phone -- what is the matter. Ring him -- ring him. Where are you -- where are you, Cherie? Why don't you answer? Well, ring him -- please -- please.

question: The night clerk has already gone -- you are late.
answer: Man -- I was at the clinic the whole night -- there are no words to describe what my wife suffered.

question: And the child isn't coming?
answer: No -- no -- not yet. Well, I mustn't let it interfere with my duty. Any news here?

question: News? Yes -- killing in number one- sixty-four.
answer: What? -- Who? -- Whom?

question: The big manufacturer killed Baron von Gaigern.
answer: Good heavens. What for?

question: I don't know.
answer: Man -- that's terrible. He was a nice fellow -- I am sorry about him.

question: It seems that he was a thief and an imposter.
answer: I don't believe it -- he was a real gentleman. I know people... I'm so tired I can hardly see out of my eyes. No sleep for two nights and so many duties and now this killing in the hotel -- that means a lot of work. But it's too bad about the Baron, you always felt better when he came along -- always friendly -- such an agreeable fellow.

question: Most imposters are --
answer: Good morning. Show your hands. You have dirty nails -- you little pig -- you're no good... Caps off! -- Let's see your hair. Good -- caps on! Where is number seven?... Not here? Take his name -- if he comes late again today, he's fired. Dismissed!

question: What's the matter?
answer: Oh -- I was thinking -- Poor Baron -- Lying there, his eyes so open.

question: You loved the Baron, didn't you?
answer: Yes --

question: So did I. He was friendly to me as no man ever was.
answer: Perhaps he really was a burglar -- But they don't kill a man for that.

question: He was in desperate straits. He'd been trying to raise money all day. He laughed -- Poor devil! And then a man like Preysing kills him.
answer: I didn't like Preysing right off.

question: Then why did you have anything to do with him?
answer: Money!

question: Yes, of course, -- money!
answer: You don't understand that do you?

question: Of course I do -- I never knew what money really meant till I started spending it. Do you know -- I can hardly believe that anything so beautiful should come to me from Preysing -- I'll take care of you. Will -- will you let me?
answer: What?

question: You'll have a good time with me. Want to? I've got enough money. Ten thousand two hundred in my pocketbook. Three thousand four hundred that I won. It will last a long time. I can win more -- we'll travel.
answer: Yes -- to Paris? I wanted to go there always.

question: Wherever you like. Here I'll give you the money I won, three thousand four hundred. Later you can have more.
answer: Later?

question: When I -- I'm ill, Flaemmchen -- It will not be long -- I'll not last long. Will you stay with me until...
answer: Nonsense! We'll find a great doctor, he'll cure you. They can cure anything these days.

question: Do you believe that you will have a better time with me than you would with Preysing?
answer: Oh yes, of course.

question: Do you like me better?
answer: You're a good man, Mr. Kringelein -- a very good man.
